event.title: the next three months, Czech Foreign Minister Karel Schwarzenberg said

data.event: The Czech EU presidency is not happy with some Israeli policies and an EU-Israel summit is unlikely to take place in the next three months, Czech Foreign Minister Karel Schwarzenberg said on Tuesday.

event.title: works close to Jerusalem but also access to Gaza, which is today

data.event: "We are not happy with some of the steps of the Israeli government, namely construction works close to Jerusalem but also access to Gaza, which is today very limited," daily Lidove Noviny quoted Schwarzenberg as saying.

event.title: a campaign a few days ago

data.event: International trepidation over the incoming government's righward orientation prompted President Shimom Peres to launch a campaign a few days ago whose aim is to convince the world that the "Netanyahu-Lieberman-Barak" government will advance the peace process with the Palestinians.

Sources close to Peres said yesterday that the president has transmitted similar messages in his talks with foreign leaders, which are expected to continue through Wednesday, when the new government is to be sworn in.

event.title: an official visit to Prague on Monday

data.event: Peres made an official visit to Prague on Monday, where he met with the president, prime minister and foreign minister of the Czech Republic.
In addition, immediately after the swearing-in ceremony for Netanyahu on Wednesday, Peres will launch a media blitz of interviews to the foreign press to explain the policies of the new government.
